description.plain:
The Velvet Underground was an American rock band formed in New York City. First active from 1964 to 1973, its best-known members were Lou Reed and John Cale, who both went on to find success as solo artists. Although experiencing little commercial success while together, the band is often cited by many critics as one of the most important and influential groups of the 1960s. In a 1982 interview Brian Eno made the often repeated statement that while the first Velvet Underground album may have sold only 30,000 copies in its early years, “everyone who bought one of those 30,000 copies started a band.”

Andy Warhol managed the Velvet Underground and it was the house band at his studio, the Factory, and his Exploding Plastic Inevitable events. The provocative lyrics of some of the band’s songs gave a nihilistic outlook to some of their music.

Their 1967 debut album, The Velvet Underground & Nico (which featured German singer Nico, with whom the band collaborated), was named the 13th Greatest Album of All Time, and the “most prophetic rock album ever made” by Rolling Stone in 2003. In 2004, Rolling Stone ranked the band No. 19 on its list of the “100 Greatest Artists of All Time”. The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1996, by Patti Smith.

songs.full_title: Heroin by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Heroin

description.plain:
While there are many alternative interpretations of this song, it seems to be the case that Lou Reed was merely describing the effects of the drug, while neither condemning it nor condoning it. It might have been done merely for shock value, or because Reed liked gritty subjects, or as a dark poem of addiction; the beauty of this song is that it works on all of these levels, and many more, at the same time. In many of his songs, we have cases where Lou Reed kept the focus on providing an objective description of the topic without taking a moral stance on thematter.

(From Songfacts)

The desire for something you can’t describe… This is about a guy who is jumping towards God or the perfection of Jesus. There’s a ferocious desire within the song to solve a problem. He doesn’t have much left apart from a desire to score; spiritually he’s bereft, but he thinks if he can get his fix, life will become better. I don’t know if it’s about a specific person, more likely an amalgamation, but it’s a beautiful portrayal of someone at their wits’ end.

– John Cale in an interview with Uncut

Lou Reed wrote “Heroin” while attending Syracuse University – he would have been close to the age of 18.

I don't know just where I'm goin'
But I'm gonna try for the kingdom, if I can
'Cause it makes me feel like I'm a man
When I put a spike into my vein
And I tell you things aren't quite the same
When I'm rushin' on my run
And I feel just like Jesus' son
And I guess that I just don't know
And I guess that I just don't know

[Verse 2]
I have made big decision
I'm gonna try to nullify my life
'Cause when the blood begins to flow
When it shoots up the dropper's neck
When I'm closin' in on death
You can't help me, not you guys
Or all you sweet girls with all your sweet talk
You can all go take a walk
And I guess I just don't know
And I guess that I just don't know

[Verse 3]
I wish that I was born a thousand years ago
I wish that I'd sailed the darkened seas
On a great big clipper ship
Goin' from this land here to that
On a sailor's suit and cap
Away from the big city
Where a man cannot be free
Of all the evils of this town
And of himself and those around
Oh, and I guess that I just don't know
Oh, and I guess that I just don't know
[Verse 4]
Heroin, be the death of me
Heroin, it's my wife and it's my life, haha
Because a mainline into my vein
Leads to a center in my head
And then I'm better off than dead
Because when the smack begins to flow
I really don't care anymore
About all the Jim-Jims in this town
And all the politicians makin' crazy sounds
And everybody puttin' everybody else down
And all the dead bodies piled up in mounds

'Cause when the smack begins to flow
And I really don't care anymore
Ah, when that heroin is in my blood
Heh, and that blood is in my head
Then thank God that I'm good as dead
And thank your God that I'm not aware
And thank God that I just don't care
And I guess I just don't know

songs.full_title: Sunday Morning by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Sunday Morning

description.plain:
“Sunday Morning” is the opening song to The Velvet Underground’s debut album, The Velvet Underground & Nico. The song describes the feeling of staying up all Saturday night into Sunday morning. Aptly, Reed & Cale wrote the song after one of those nights at 6 AM on a Sunday morning. As Cale remembered in a 2006 interview with Uncut:

Lou and I had been up all night on crank, as usual, so we decided to visit one of his old Syracuse college pals. Unfortunately, this guy’s upper-middle-class wife didn’t appreciate visits from old college pals high on amphetamines, at 3am, who wanted to play music. He had a guitar which Lou picked up and the evening inspired him to write the song.

The most polished song on the album, “Sunday Morning” was released as a single in December 1966. MGM/Verve spent little, if any effort to promote it and it sunk, unnoticed, on release. However, it grew in popularity through radio play by DJs like John Peel and Dick Summer, sowing the seeds for the Velvets' cult following.

The band made a live version of the song for their last concert with Lou, on the album Live at Max’s Kansas City, where Reed introduces the song with: “This is a song about when you’ve done something so sad and you wake up the next day and you remember it. Not to sound grim or anything… just, once in a while, you have one of those days.”
This can bring another meaning to the song. A song of regret and, maybe, of a new dawn that would represent forgiveness (“[…]always some around you who will call. It’s nothing at all”).

songs.full_title: Pale Blue Eyes by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Pale Blue Eyes

description.plain:
“Pale Blue Eyes” is a song written by Lou Reed for The Velvet Underground’s 1969 album, The Velvet Underground.

The song was written for Reed’s first serious girlfriend and true love, Shelley Albin. Although Shelley wasn’t married and did not have blue eyes (details he changed to make the song work), he tried many times to get her back, and therefore what he “had but couldn’t keep.” (“Lou Reed” by Anthony DeCurtis, page 49)

[Verse 1]
Sometimes I feel so happy
Sometimes I feel so sad
Sometimes I feel so happy
But mostly, you just make me mad
Baby, you just make me mad

[Chorus]

Linger on your pale blue eyes

Thought of you as my mountain top
Thought of you as my peak
Thought of you as everything

And strange as what I see
I'd put you in the mirror
I put in front of me

Linger on your pale blue eyes

[Instrumental Break]

[Verse 4]
Skip a life completely
Stuff it in a cup
She said, "Money is like us in time
It lies but can't stand up
Down for you is up"

[Chorus]

It was good what we did yesterday
And I'll do it once again
The fact that you are married
Only proves you're my best friend
But it's truly, truly a sin

songs.full_title: Venus in Furs by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Venus in Furs

description.plain:
This song is named for, and based on, Leopold von Sacher-Masoch’s 1870 novella Venus in Furs, in which the male main character seeks to be enslaved by his fur-adorned lover.

The song and its topic challenged songwriting conventions at the time, the celebration of sexual masochism out in the open wasn’t something you heard every day. The word “masochism”, coined by 19th century sexologist Richard von Krafft-Ebing, also comes from Sacher-Masoch’s name, so dude wasn’t kidding around.

Downy sins of streetlight fancies

I am tired, I am weary

songs.full_title: I’m Waiting for the Man by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: I’m Waiting for the Man

description.plain:
“I’m Waiting for the Man” visually describes the experience of buying heroin from a dealer, specifically $26 worth near the intersection of Lexington Avenue and 125th Street in New York City.

“I’m Waiting For The Man” marks the beginning of a common motif that runs throughout The Velvet Underground & Nico, as the subject of heroin appears in several tracks afterwards.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
I'm waiting for my man
Twenty-six dollars in my hand
Up to Lexington, 125
Feel sick and dirty, more dead than alive
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 2]
Hey, white boy, what you doin' uptown?
Hey, white boy, you chasin' our women around?
Oh pardon me sir, it's furthest from my mind
I'm just lookin' for a dear, dear friend of mine
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 3]
Here he comes, he's all dressed in black
PR shoes and a big straw hat
He's never early, he's always late
First thing you learn is that you always gotta wait
I'm waiting for my man
Oh, work it now

[Instrumental Break]

[Verse 4]
Up to a brownstone, up three flights of stairs
Everybody bodies pinned you, but nobody cares
He's got the works, gives you sweet taste
Ah, then you gotta split because you got no time to waste
I'm waiting for my man
[Verse 5]
Baby don't you holler, darlin' don't you bawl and shout
I'm feeling good, you know I'm gonna work it on out
I'm feeling good, I'm feeling, oh, so fine
Until tomorrow, but that's just some other time
I'm waiting for my man
Walk it home

[Outro]
Oh, it's alright
Huh huh4EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Sweet Jane by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Sweet Jane

description.plain: Possibly the most commercially viable song ever recorded by The VU. From their final official album with Lou Reed as a member, the song, and many others on the album, were a departure from the grittier, and darker material from their previous 3 albums. At the insistence of their record label, they were asked to record a album loaded with hits, and the album was named Loaded. The song is today among the most recognizable of the band’s songs.

songs.full_title: Femme Fatale by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Femme Fatale

description.plain: “Femme Fatale” was written at Andy Warhol’s request as a tribute to infamous Warhol Superstar; Edie Sedgwick. A fiercely beautiful and seductive woman with an enchanting allure. Sedgwick died at 28 from an accidental prescription medication overdose, the climax of the downward spiral during the final years of her life. Despite the many tragedies she lived through, her beauty and unforgettable aura have crafted her into one of the most famous beauty icons of her era.

songs.full_title: I'll Be Your Mirror by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: I’ll Be Your Mirror

description.plain:
Sung by the German singer Nico, who was a Warhol Superstar around the time the album was released,  the song is about the wish of a person that wants to share the beauty that a loved one possesses and the person sees, with the purpose that he/she appreciate themselves.

The song was not written for Nico, as Lou Reed wrote it during his time at Syracuse before he ever met her. It was one of the songs he reluctantly allowed Nico – who then accompanied the band on stage – to sing on the record, as a request by Warhol. But if we understand that the songs she sings somehow became emblematic of Nico’s troubled relationship with Reed, it shows a much gentler side of the relationship than the two other songs he gave to her: Femme Fatale and All Tomorrow’s Parties.

songs.full_title: After Hours by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: After Hours

description.plain:
The final track on the Velvet Underground’s self-titled third album, “After Hours” speaks to nights that don’t end such that one would “never have to see the day again.” Yet, with Maureen Tucker’s angelic voice, it’s more a lullaby (in spite of the chorus).

When introducing the song in a later version found on The Bootleg Series Vol. 1 – The Quine Tapes, Lou Reed states that the song is “for people who like to drink around 6 in the morning at after hours bars”

songs.full_title: Run Run Run by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Run Run Run

description.plain:
Run Run Run follows a number of characters; Teenage Mary, Margarita Passion, Seasick Sarah, and Beardless Harry, all of whom are seeking drugs or engaging in acts of drug use.

Written on the back of an envelope by front man Lou Reed while he and the band were on their way to a gig at the “Cafe Bizarre”.

songs.full_title: All Tomorrow's Parties by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: All Tomorrow’s Parties

description.plain:
From songfacts.com:

This is reportedly Andy Warhol’s favorite Velvet Underground song, though probably more for having Nico (born Christa Päffgen) sing the lead than Velvet Underground’s part in it. It was about a 50/50 shot whether flyers and posters for Exploding Plastic Inevitable performances around this time would have Nico’s name before Velvet Underground’s – with Nico sometimes billed as “pop girl of ‘66.” In the pages of the Village Voice, rock critic Richard Goldstein called Nico “half goddess, half icicle,” and reviewed her, saying “She sings in perfect mellow ovals. It sounds something like a cello getting up in the morning.”

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
And what costume shall the poor girl wear
To all tomorrow's parties?
A hand-me-down dress from who knows where
To all tomorrow's parties
And where will she go and what shall she do
When midnight comes around?
She'll turn once more to Sunday's clown
And cry behind the door

[Guitar Solo]

[Verse 2]
And what costume shall the poor girl wear
To all tomorrow's parties?
Why silks and linens of yesterday's gowns
To all tomorrow's parties?
And what will she do with Thursday's rags
When Monday comes around?
She'll turn once more to Sunday's clown
And cry behind the door

[Guitar Solo]

[Verse 3]
And what costume shall the poor girl wear
To all tomorrow's parties?
For Thursday's child is Sunday's clown
For whom none will go mourning
A blackened shroud, a hand-me-down gown
Of rags and silks, a costume
Fit for one who sits and cries
For all tomorrow's parties13EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Candy Says by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Candy Says

description.plain:
First track on The Velvet Underground’s eponymous third album (1969)



Written by Lou Reed, but sung by bassist Doug Yule “as a matter of circumstance”, according to guitarist Sterling Morrison:

 … when we did the third album, we were in the midst of touring the West Coast. During any interludes in that tour, we’d run into the studio, and that always tore Lou’s voice up. If he sounded particularly froggy, just to get the track complete or get a vocal on there, we would have Doug sing it. He did a fair amount of singing on the third album and the explanation was purely physiological.

songs.full_title: Oh! Sweet Nuthin' by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Oh! Sweet Nuthin’

description.plain:
Although it may sound closer to blues, country and classic rock, “Oh! Sweet Nuthin'”  – the closing song off of Loaded, truly represents the reason why the Velvet Underground is acclaimed as the pioneers of punk: it is  quite a powerful track based solely on three chords.

Lyrically, it sounds a bit like a precursor to “Walk on the Wild Side”: Lou Reed presents a panel of characters inhabiting the underbelly of a metropolis:

It tells the stories of the disaffected, the poor Jimmy Brown, the homeless and depressed Ginger Brown, his fellow street person Polly May, and poor Joanna Love who finds herself in an endless stream of failed relationships. (source).

However, different from “Walk on the Wild Side”, the characters here don’t seem to be based on specific people, they’re more like archetypes.

This is one of the songs in which Doug Yule had the most input: he recorded the drums, the vocals and the guitar solo.

songs.full_title: Sister Ray by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Sister Ray

description.plain:
A preternaturally influential noise-rock jam that constituted most of side two of White Light/White Heat (the rest of it was taken up by another noisy rocker, “I Heard Her Call My Name”). Even though it may sound less brain-melting now that its feedback laden sound has become a part of the indie rock and punk mainframe, it still packs a punch.

Supposedly, while recording the song, the band did it all in one take, leaving in all mistakes and inconsistencies. Producer Tom Wilson, so shocked by the chaotic squall the band was playing, walked out in the middle of recording.

The song is about an 1800’s orgy featuring 7 characters and implies heavy heroin use.

songs.full_title: The Gift by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: The Gift

description.plain:
This track features, in the left channel, Velvet Underground’s violist John Cale reading, in his thick Welsh accent, a morbidly humorous short story written by Lou Reed for a creative writing class, while the rest of the band performs a loud jam in the right channel. It is the second track on the Velvet Underground’s second album White Light/White Heat.

Reed:

The idea was two things going at once – Cale in one stereo channel, music in the other – If you got tired of the words, you could just listen to the instrumental.

songs.full_title: The Gift [Live MCMXCIII] by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: The Gift [Live MCMXCIII]

songs.lyrics:
Waldo Jeffers had reached his limit. It was now mid-August, which meant he had been separated from Marsha for more than two months. Two months, and all he had to show was three dog-eared letters and two very expensive long-distance phone calls. True, when school had ended and she'd returned to Wisconsin, and he to Locust, Pennsylvania, she had sworn to maintain a certain fidelity. She would date occasionally, but merely as amusement. She would remain faithful

But lately Waldo had begun to worry. He had trouble sleeping at night and when he did, he had horrible dreams. He lay awake at night, tossing and turning underneath his pleated quilt protector, tears welling in his eyes as he pictured Marsha, her sworn vows overcome by liquor and the smooth soothings of some neanderthal, finally submitting to the final caresses of sexual oblivion. It was more than the human mind could bear

Visions of Marsha's faithlessness haunted him. Daytime fantasies of sexual abandon permeated his thoughts. And the thing was, they wouldn't understand how she really was. He, Waldo, alone understood this. He had intuitively grasped every nook and cranny of her psyche. He had made her smile. She needed him, and he wasn't there. (Awww...)

The idea came to him on the Thursday before the Mummers' Parade was scheduled to appear. He'd just finished mowing and edging the Edelsons' lawn for a dollar fifty and had checked the mailbox to see if there was at least a word from Marsha. There was nothing but a circular from the Amalgamated Aluminum Company of America inquiring into his awning needs. At least they cared enough to write

It was a New York company. You could go anywhere in the mails. Then it struck him. He didn't have enough money to go to Wisconsin in the accepted fashion, true, but why not mail himself? It was absurdly simple. He would ship himself parcel post, special delivery. The next day Waldo went to the supermarket to purchase the necessary equipment. He bought masking tape, a staple gun and a medium sized cardboard box just right for a person of his build. He judged that with a minimum of jostling he could ride quite comfortably. A few air holes, some water, perhaps some midnight snacks, and it would probably be as good as going tourist!

By Friday afternoon, Waldo was set. He was thoroughly packed and the Post Office had agreed to pick him up at three o'clock. He'd marked the package "Fragile", and as he sat curled up inside, resting on the foam rubber cushioning he'd thoughtfully included, he tried to picture the look of awe and happiness on Marsha's face as she opened her door, saw the package, tipped the deliverer, and then opened it to see her Waldo finally there in person. She would kiss him, and then maybe they could see a movie. If he'd only thought of this before. Suddenly rough hands gripped his package and he felt himself borne up. He landed with a thud in a truck and was off

Marsha Bronson had just finished setting her hair. It had been a very rough weekend. She had to remember not to drink like that. Bill had been nice about it though. After it was over he'd said he still respected her and, after all, it was certainly the way of nature, and even though, no, he didn't love her, he did feel an affection for her. And after all, they were grown adults. Oh, what Bill could teach Waldo! But that seemed many years ago

Sheila Klein, her very, very best friend, walked in through the porch screen door and into the kitchen. "Oh gawd, it's absolutely maudlin outside."
"Ach, I know what you mean, I feel all icky!"
Marsha tightened the belt on her cotton robe with the silk outer edge. Sheila ran her finger over some salt grains on the kitchen table, licked her finger and made a face. "I'm supposed to be taking these salt pills, but," she wrinkled her nose, "they make me feel like throwing up." Marsha started to pat herself under the chin, an exercise she'd seen on television. "God, don't even talk about that." She got up from the table and went to the sink where she picked up a bottle of pink and blue vitamins. "Want one? Supposed to be better than steak," and then attempted to touch her knees. "I don't think I'll ever touch a daiquiri again."

She gave up and sat down, this time nearer the small table that supported the telephone. "Maybe Bill'll call," she said to Sheila's glance. Sheila nibbled on a cuticle. "After last night, I thought maybe you'd be through with him." "I know what you mean. My God, he was like an octopus. Hands all over the place." She gestured, raising her arms upwards in defense. "The thing is, after a while, you get tired of fighting with him, you know, and after all I didn't really do anything Friday and Saturday so I kind of owed it to him. You know what I mean." She started to scratch. Sheila was giggling with her hand over her mouth. "I'll tell you, I felt the same way, and even after a while," here she bent forward in a whisper, "I wanted to!" Now she was laughing very loudly

It was at this point that Mr. Jameson of the Clarence Darrow Post Office rang the doorbell of the large stucco-colored frame house. When Marsha Bronson opened the door, he helped her carry the package in. He had his yellow and his green slips of paper signed and left with a fifteen cent tip that Marsha had gotten out of her mother's small beige pocketbook in the den
"What do you think it is?" Sheila asked. Marsha stood with her arms folded behind her back. She stared at the brown cardboard carton that sat in the middle of the living room. "I dunno."

Inside the package, Waldo quivered with excitement as he listened to the muffled voices. Sheila ran her fingernail over the masking tape that ran down the center of the carton. "Why don't you look at the return address and see who it's from?" Waldo felt his heart beating. He could feel the vibrating footsteps. It would be soon!

Marsha walked around the carton and read the ink-scratched label. "Ah, god it's from Waldo!"
"That schmuck!" said Sheila. Waldo trembled with expectation. "Well, you might as well open it," said Sheila. Both of them tried to lift the staple flap
"Ah sst," said Marsha, groaning, "he must have nailed it shut." They tugged on the flap again. "My God, you need a power drill to get this thing open!" They pulled again. "You can't get a grip." They both stood still, breathing heavily
"Why don't you get a scissor," said Sheila. Marsha ran into the kitchen, but all she could find was a little sewing scissor. Then she remembered that her father kept a collection of tools in the basement. She ran downstairs, and when she came back up, she had a large sheet metal cutter in her hand. "This is the best I could find." She was very out of breath. "Here, you do it. I-I'm gonna die." She sank into a large fluffy couch and exhaled noisily. Sheila tried to make a slit between the masking tape and the end of the cardboard flap, but the blade was too big and there wasn't enough room. "God damn this thing!" she said, feeling very exasperated. Then smiling, "I got an idea."
"What?" said Marsha
"Just watch," said Sheila, touching her finger to her head

Inside the package, Waldo was so transfixed with excitement that he could barely breathe. His skin felt prickly from the heat, and he could feel his heart beating in his throat. It would be soon. Sheila stood quite upright and walked around to the other side of the package. Then she sank down to her knees, grasped the cutter by both handles, took a deep breath, and plunged the long blade through the middle of the package, through the masking tape, through the cardboard, through the cushioning and (thud) right through the center of Waldo Jeffers' head, which split slightly and caused little rhythmic arcs of red to pulsate gently in the morning sun7EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Lady Godiva’s Operation

description.plain:
The 3rd track on the classic Velvet Underground album, White Light/White Heat. This song is about a botched lobotomy on a transsexual woman.



John Cale called it “a BBC Radiophonic Workshop idea … a radio-theatre piece, trying to use the studio to create this panorama of a story”.

songs.full_title: White Light/White Heat by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: White Light/White Heat

description.plain:
The most common interpretation of “White Light/White Heat” is that it is about shooting methamphetamine. Musically and lyrically it would be something like the speed version of “Heroin”, the frantic rhythm and somewhat laconic lyrics mimicking the frenzy of a meth rush, the light and heat being the physical sensations provoked by it.

Reed has confirmed it being about meth in interviews:

The lyrics aren’t negative … “White Light/White Heat” – it has to do with methamphetamine. “Sister Ray” is all about that. But they are telling you stories – and feelings. They are not stupid. And the rhythm is interesting. But you’d think that. I studied long enough.



There is another less know interpretation, based on an interview Lou Reed gave to KVAN radio in 1969: that white light is a reference to Eastern and occult metaphysical concepts Reed was studying at the time:

I’ve been involved and interested in what they call “white light” for a long time … that’s a way of giving off white light.”

In the same interview, Reed also reference a book called A Treatise on White Magic, by Alice Bailey, which includes instructions on how to “call down a stream of pure White Light”. (source).



Both interpretations are not mutually exclusive, as an interest in both drugs and Eastern and unorthodox philosophies was popular among American counterculture movements at least since the beatnicks.

songs.full_title: European Son by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: European Son

description.plain:
Dedicated to Reed’s teacher at Syracuse University, Delmore Schwartz.



Sterling Morrison said:

Everyone thinks it’s because the song is thematically appropriate: “You killed your European son/you spit on those under 21”. Incidentally that may be true because Delmore was the son of Jewish emigres and a great poet, who was never accepted, but the real reason is that it has only two stanzas of lyrics and a long instrumental break. Delmore thought rock and roll lyrics were the worst things he’d ever heard in his life; he despised songs with words. As this was our big instrumental outing on the album we dedicated it to him.

songs.full_title: Rock & Roll by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Rock & Roll

description.plain: The 3rd song from The VU’s last album with Lou Reed as a member, it is a story of a girl, Jennie, who discovers Rock and Roll at the tender age of 5, and it would end up saving her life. Jennie is based on Reed himself, a fact that he has admitted. The song is about hearing Elvis Presley’s ‘Heartbreak Hotel’ on the radio, which changed the lives and inspired many 60s rock icons.

songs.full_title: Stephanie Says by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Stephanie Says

description.plain:
“Stephanie Says” was originally recorded February 13, 1968, shortly after the release of White Light/White Heat. It’s one of the final Velvet Underground recordings to feature John Cale, who was fired shortly after these sessions by Lou Reed.

Reed later rewrote this song and included it in his 1973 album Berlin as “Caroline Says II”.

songs.full_title: The Murder Mystery by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: The Murder Mystery

description.plain:
The penultimate track on the group’s 3rd album: The Velvet Underground. It is an overwhelming 9 minute track, featuring two layers of vocals played over each other. From the left speaker Morrison and Tucker and Yule and Reed singing from the left. The odd verses are spoken in beat, while the even verses are sung slowly. The track ends with slower and choppier speaking in the final verse.



On the booklet accompanying the box-set ‘Peel Slowly and See’, Reed laments the final version of the song:

Good try, but it didn’t work. It couldn’t be recorded that well. The idea was simple – have two lyrics running at the same time so you get hit with one monologue in one ear and the other monologue in the other ear, like two guitar parts. Just as two guitar parts are supposed to interweave, so are these two poems. But it didn’t work because you couldn’t hear either one well enough to hear what was being said. It was supposed to be fun with words, fun with rhymes and sounds.

For similar reasons, critics Lester Bangs, in his Rolling Stone review also saw the song as a low point on the album:

‘The Murder Mystery’ is an eight minute exercise in aural overload that annoys after a few listenings.

The fact that the band and the critic were unhappy with the result don’t make the song less powerful, though.

On the same booklet, Morrison described his guitar riff in the song as “sort of like the fright music in a B-movie serial”.

songs.full_title: Some Kinda Love by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Some Kinda Love

description.plain:
In the beginning of the first version of the song from 11/26/69 (released as The Complete Matrix Tapes), Lou Reed states that the song is “an alcoholic’s dream realized”.

There are two different mixes for the 1968 Velvet Underground album. The one done by MGM engineer Val Valentin was the one that was released originally. But Lou Reed did another one, highlighting his vocals and guitars, which came to be known as the “closet mix”.

The main difference between these mixes is in “Some Kinda Love”, because each uses a totally different take from the same sessions.

https://youtu.be/g2MjIxeLluo

The Misfits did a sort of response to this song called “Some Kinda Hate”.

Some kinds of love, Marguerita told Tom
Between thought and expression lies a lifetime
Situations arise because of the weather
And no kinds of love are better than others

Like a dirty French novel combines the absurd with the vulgar

And of course you're a bore but in that you're not charmless

And some kinds of love are mistaken for vision

[Verse 4]
Put jelly on your shoulder let us do what you fear most
That from which you recoil but which still makes your eyes moist
Put jelly on your shoulder baby, lie down upon the carpet
Between thought and expression let us now kiss the culprit, move it on

[Outro]
I don't know just what it's all about
But put on your red pajamas and find out1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: What Goes On by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: What Goes On

description.plain:
“What goes on”  was the only single released from The Velvet Underground’s 1969 eponymous third album.

As others VU songs, it had inspired countless artists to perform alternative covers for the song, some of them are Bryan Ferry, Elizabeth Mitchel, The Screaming Trees, and Toy.

The organ riff of the song was also used in the Talking Heads song “Once in a Lifetime”.

In the fans Timothy Bracy and Elizabeth Bracy’s words the song:

is one of those unmistakably great grooves that only the Velvets seem to be able to manage … a sophisticated melding of chugging guitars, clever chord changes, and sublime arrangement.

songs.full_title: Here She Comes Now by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Here She Comes Now

description.plain:
The 4th track on White Light/White Heat “Here She Comes Now” is an oasis of tranquility and relative simplicity in an album otherwise characterized by punishing noise and anarchic experimentation.

The song was written before The Velvet Underground & Nico was released and a demo version with completely different lyrics was even recorded back in 1967.

Like most softer songs from the first album, Nico was considered to assume the vocals, and she even sung it with the band during Exploding Plastic Inevitable performances (recordings of which, unfortunately, have never surfaced). However, by the time the band recorded the song, Nico was no longer collaborating with them.

The subject matter is elusive and open to interpretation. Sex and drugs have been suggested, but many believe it to be about Lou Reed’s Ostrich guitar (hence the otherwise bizarre line “made out of wood”).

songs.full_title: Jesus by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Jesus

description.plain:
“Jesus” belongs to a three part story featured in the album, starting here and continuing on in “Beginning To See The Light” and “I’m Set Free”.

The narrator seeks to find Jesus in the first song, discovers his faith and begins to “See the light of God” and then feels he is set free from all liabilities now that he has religion. Ironically, Lou Reed was Jewish, not Christian.

Keeping in line with the rest of the album’s more restrained nuanced sound, “Jesus” is stripped of any embellishment, just Reed’s vocals and two mellow acoustic guitars.

songs.full_title: New Age by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: New Age

description.plain:
One of the songs in Loaded written by Lou Reed and sung by Doug Yule. John Cale , who had by then officially left the band, plays organ.



The lyrics were written from the point of view of a fan infatuated with an actress who’d seen better years.

And early version available on * 1969: The Velvet Underground Live* had Reed on vocals and a completely different lyrics, addressing his girlfriend at the time, Shelley Albin, as well as his own bisexuality.

The 1997 special edition Fully Loaded includes a “full length version” with an extra minute of music.

songs.full_title: I Heard Her Call My Name by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: I Heard Her Call My Name
songs.title_with_featured: I Heard Her Call My Name

description.plain:
“I Heard Her Call My Name”, which starts as a fairly straightforward rock song, with catchy backing vocals, has one of the loudest, weirdest and most aggressive solos in any Velvet Underground song. Maybe in any rock song up to that point. The atonal, feedback-filled solo is said to have been influenced by the Free-Jazz of Ornette Coleman. Reed said in 1989:

There were two sides of the coin for me. R&B, doo-wop, rockabilly. And then Ornette Coleman and Don Cherry, Archie Shepp, stuff like that. When I was in college, I had a jazz radio show. I called it “Excursion on a Wobbly Rail”, after a Cecil Taylor song. I used to run around the Village following Ornette Coleman wherever he played.”

This song shows both sides of that coin pretty well.

Lyrically, the narrator being crippled (disabled or damaged because of drug use), he has illusions of and hears the voice of his dead lover (or maybe his mother) calling his name. Knowing she’s long dead and gone, Lou gets his mind “split open” which may resemble the fact he can’t get his mind around the idea of him hearing his dead lover once again or a lobotomy because of the signs of a mental illness (schizophrenia). Maybe a ghost or maybe a hallucination.

songs.full_title: Ride Into the Sun (Session Outtake) by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Ride Into the Sun (Session Outtake)

description.plain:
“Ride Into the Sun” was originally recorded September 5, 1969 for The Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After the band was dropped by MGM Records and the album was shelved, this song remained unreleased until Verve included it on their 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.full_title: She's My Best Friend by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: She’s My Best Friend

description.plain:
“She’s My Best Friend” was originally recorded May 14, 1969, during the sessions for the Velvet Underground’s lost fourth album. After the band was dropped by MGM Records, the sessions for this album were scrapped and thrown into the MGM vault, where they remained until Verve issued them in 1985 on the archival album VU.

Lou Reed later re-recorded this song for inclusion on his 1976 album Coney Island Baby.

songs.full_title: I Can't Stand It by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: I Can’t Stand It

description.plain:
“I Can’t Stand It” was originally recorded May 20, 1969, during the sessions for the Velvet Underground’s lost fourth album. It was discarded after the band was dropped from MGM Records and the planned album was thrown out.

Lou Reed later re-recorded this song for inclusion on his first solo album, Lou Reed.

annotatable.link_title: I Can’t Stand It by The Velvet Underground
annotatable.title: I Can't Stand It

body.plain:
“I Can’t Stand It” was originally recorded May 20, 1969, during the sessions for the Velvet Underground’s lost fourth album. It was discarded after the band was dropped from MGM Records and the planned album was thrown out.

Lou Reed later re-recorded this song for inclusion on his first solo album, Lou Reed.

songs.full_title: Over You [1969 The Velvet Underground Live] by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Over You [1969 The Velvet Underground Live]
songs.title_with_featured: Over You [1969 The Velvet Underground Live]

description.plain:
“Over You” is a simple, acoustic ballad that focuses on the repetitive nature of developing feelings for someone you have idealised.

It is notably recorded straight from a vinyl edition of the album, unlike most of the album which uses original sources.

A later version recorded in 1969 appears on The Bootleg Series Vol.1 – The Quine Tapes, which comprises of Robert Quine’s cassette recordings of the band performing live. In his recording of Over You, Lou Reed changes the lyrics:


Oh, here I go again
You know I’m feelin' real silly again
Ah, I’m on my feet again
Over you [x2]

Oh, I’m on my feet again
You know that I’m like a bell that rings
I’m feelin' so fine again
Over you [x2]

Typically, when I had it
I treated it like dirt
Naturally now, I want it
I keep chasin' yesterdays rainbows

Oh, here I go again
You know I’m feelin' real silly again
Oh, I’m like a mad fool again
Over you [x2]

Oh, I’m like a bell that rings
I’m like a flower that waits to spring
Oh I – Here I go again
Over you [x4]


Another version of “Over You” appears on 1969: The Velvet Underground Live. In this version, Reed again changes the lyrics:


Here I go again
Oh, I’m acting like a fool again
Just a fool again
Over you [x2]

I guess I’m just like a bell that rings
Yeah, I’m just like a summer without a spring
Guess I’m just like everything
Over you [x2]

Naturally, when I had it
I treated it like dirt
Now, typically I want it
I keep chasing less and less rainbows

Here I go again
I guess I’m acting like a fool again
Acting stupid again
Over you [x2]

I guess I’m just like a bell that rings
I guess I’m just like everything
Just like a summer without a spring
Over you [x3]

songs.full_title: Lisa Says by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Lisa Says

description.plain:
“Lisa Says” was originally recorded October 1, 1969 during the sessions for the Velvet Underground’s lost fourth album. After the band was dropped by MGM Records, the sessions were shelved and the album didn’t see the light of day again until Verve issued them on the 1985 archival album VU.

Lou Reed later re-recorded this song with different lyrics for inclusion on his 1972 solo album Lou Reed.

songs.full_title: Train Round the Bend by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Train Round the Bend

description.plain:
Direct contradiction of “Up Around the Bend” by Creedence Clearwater Revival, released three months earlier.  There: “Hitch a ride to the end of the highway Where the neons turn to wood.” Here: “Hey, I am just a city boy
I’m really not the country kind
Oh, I miss the city streets and the neon lights.”

body.plain: The last Velvet song to include John Cale, this song’s clever studio play epitomizes the sort of literary fun and pop musical experimentation that the Velvets were all about

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1: Lou Reed, John Cale]
(Somebody shut the door)
I know where temptation lies
Inside of you heart
(You can talk during this)
I know where the evil lies
Inside of your heart
(Well get out of here)
If you're gonna try to make it right
You're surely gonna end up wrong
Wrong wrong wrong wrong
(Oh shut the door)
(Ahh)
(That's the only chord I know)

[Verse 2: Reed, Cale]
I know where the mirror's edge
Is inside of your heart
(She didn't pay a dollar tonight)
I know where the razors edge
Is inside of your heart (Motown)
(It's not even within five feet)
Well if you're gonna make it right
You're surely gonna end up wrong
(You don't look like Martha and the Vandellas)
(I'm just gonna start it all over again)
(Somebody get her out of here)
(Electricity comes from other planets)
(Ooh)
[Guitar Solo with Commentary: Reed, Cale]
(It's not that bad a solo)
(Four times) (Oh!)
(It's pretty together)
(You can't stay here, Yes I can)
(I can talk to myself as well)
(I'll lock the door this time)

[Verse 3: Reed]
I know where temptation lies
Inside of your heart (Yes he's ready)
I know where the evil lies
Inside of your heart (Is he ready?)
Well if you're gonna try to make it right
You're surely gonna end up wrong

[Outro: Reed]
(Oh the whole mess start again)
(Well, New York buildings are very high)
(And not at all offensive, lock the door)
(Gonna carry on at infinite length, my dear)
(The Pope in the silver castle)EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: I'm Gonna Move Right In by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: I’m Gonna Move Right In

description.plain:
“I’m Gonna Move Right In” is a song originally recorded September 27, 1969 for the Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After the band was dropped from MGM’s artist roster and the album was shelved, the song remained unreleased until Verve included it on the 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.title: One of These Days

description.plain:
The lyrics are reminiscent of the American folk song “Dink’s Song” that was first recorded being sung by a Black woman washing clothes in a migrant labor camp: “One o' dese days, an' it won’t be long,
Call my name an' I’ll be gone. Fare thee well, O Honey, fare thee well.”

Versions of Dink’s Song were later recorded by Pete Seeger, Bob Dylan, Jeff Buckley and others.

A version of the lyrics also appear in Zora Neale Hurston’s “Their Eyes Were Watching God” – “Some of dese mornin’s and it won’t be long, you gointuh wake up callin' me and Ah’ll be gone.”

songs.full_title: Andy's Chest by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Andy’s Chest

description.plain:
Lou Reed wrote this song for Andy Warhol to cheer him up after he was shot by Valerie Solanis. It’s many just a silly song to make him laugh but also tell Andy that he still cared about him, because they did have a sort of falling out.
The song describes some of the weird-os that hung around the Factory. The title literally refers to the scar on Andy’s chest following the incident, but I also took it to mean like another kind of chest, a treasure trove of sorts, a trove of weird characters.

This song was also released on Lou Reed’s Transformer

songs.lyrics:
If I could be anything in the world that flew
I would be a bat and come swooping after you
And if the last time you were here, they were a bit cuckoo
Well, you know what happens after dark
When rattlesnakes lose their skins and their hearts
And all the missionaries lose their bark

Oh, all the trees are calling after you
And all the venom snipers after you
Are all the mountains bolder after you?

If I could be anyone of the things in the world that bite
Instead of an ancient ocelot on a leash, I'd rather be a kite
And be tied to the end of your string, flying in the air at night
'Cause you know what they say about honey bears
When you shave off all their baby hair
You have a hairy-minded pink bare bear

And all the bells are rolling out for you
And all the stones are erupting out for you
And all the cheap bloodsuckers are flying after you

Yesterday, Daisy Mae and Biff were grooving on the street
And just like in a movie, her hands became her feet
Her belly button was her mouth
Which meant she tasted what she'd speak
But the funny thing is what happened to her nose
It grew until it reached all of her toes
Now when people say her feet smell, they mean her nose
And all the curtains laced with diamonds for you
And all the Roman noblemen for you
And kingdom's Christian sailors, dear, for you
And melting ice cap mountain tops for you
And knights in flaming silver robes for you
And bats, that with a kiss, turn prince for you

Swoop, swoop
Rock, rock
Roll, roll
Swoop, swoop
Rock, rock
Roll, roll
Swoop, swoop
Rock, rockEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: We're Gonna Have a Real Good Time Together by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: We’re Gonna Have a Real Good Time Together
songs.title_with_featured: We're Gonna Have a Real Good Time Together

description.plain:
“We’re Gonna Have a Real Good Time Together” was originally recorded on September 30, 1969 for the Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After MGM dropped the band from their roster and shelved the unfinished album, this song remained unreleased until Verve included it on the 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.full_title: Prominent Men by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Prominent Men

description.plain: This song is one of the first songs that the pre tucker velvets recorded in their ludlow street loft on a tape machine left behind by tony conrad. It is the song most often cited when establishing Bob Dylan’s influence on Lou Reed for obvious reasons, the folky harmonica, the social aware protest themes, etc.

songs.lyrics:
[Lou Reed]
Through all of the highways, the byways I've travelled
Through all of the side streets and alleys of sin
Through all that's been heard nothing sinks quite as low
As the prominent statements of prominent men

[Chorus: Lou Reed/John Cale]
Prominent men tell prominent stories
Prominent men tell prominent lies
Prominent men kiss the ass of Dame Fortune
Prominent men will tear out your eyes

The streets that have life with the cat's underbelly
Aligned with their tracks of a thousand good-byes
A poor woman screams with the heat of disaster
As the prominent men sit and strengthen their ties

Oh, the prominent girls of the prominent people
Make prominent dresses and prominent hair
Oh, their prominent wealth with their eyes glazed with shadow
The prominent horrors of the ghost millionaire

The shiny stained window now crackle at sunset
They shiny red dome of the heart soon must fall
This simpering vulgar at the seat of the cauldron
Those prominent men hadn't been there at all

[Chorus: Lou Reed/John Cale]
Prominent men tell prominent stories
Prominent men tell prominent lies
Prominent men kiss the ass of Dame Fortune
Prominent men will tear out your eyes

Oh, the prominent child of these prominent people
Seeks prominent schools with the finery of age
With a prominent pink of a tasteless red orchid
The prominent men casts a prominent heir

The child of the agent walks barefoot upon grass
He screams with a power that terror's green eyes
His knife harshly glistening, stabs noways and always
But those prominent men were nowhere in sight


[Chorus: Lou Reed/John Cale]
Prominent men tell prominent stories
Prominent men tell prominent lies
Prominent men kiss the ass of Dame Fortune
Prominent men will tear out your eyesEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Rock and Roll (1969 Studio Version) by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Rock and Roll (1969 Studio Version)

description.plain:
This version of “Rock and Roll” was originally recorded June 19, 1969 for The Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After the band was dropped by MGM and the planned album was shelved, the band decided to re-record this song for inclusion on their final album, Loaded. This version, however, remained unreleased until Verve included it on the 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.full_title: Coney Island Steeplechase by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Coney Island Steeplechase

description.plain:
“Coney Island Steeplechase” was originally recorded May 6, 1969 for The Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After the band was dropped by MGM and the album was shelved, this song remained unreleased until Verve included it on their 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.full_title: Hey Mr. Rain (Version II) by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Hey Mr. Rain (Version II)

description.plain:
This version of “Hey Mr. Rain” was recorded May 29, 1968, during the sessions for The Velvet Underground’s self-titled third album.

The band decided to leave it off the album, and the song remained unreleased until Verve included it on the 1986 outtakes compilation Another View – with a separate take of this song from the same session.

songs.full_title: Booker T by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Booker T

description.plain:
This instrumental track was never recorded in a studio by the Velvets, and is only known as a live recording from a 1967 concert from the Exploding Plastic Inevitable Tour, still featuring John Cale. Released in its live version in 1991 by Italian bootleggers, it officially came out 4 years later in the Peel Slowly and See box-set.

Rumoured to be the same song played in the instrumental channel in The Gift, it surely bares resemblances to it, but David Fricke denied the identity of the songs in a 2013 essay on the liner notes of the 45th Anniversary Edition of White Light/White Heat.

The title is most likely an homage to the  rhythm and blues group Booker T. & The MG’s, whose instrumental numbers probably influenced this track.

songs.full_title: Hey Mr. Rain (Version I) by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Hey Mr. Rain (Version I)

description.plain:
This version of “Hey Mr. Rain” was recorded May 29, 1968 – it’s ostensibly an outtake from the sessions for The Velvet Underground’s self-titled third album.

It remained unreleased until Verve included it on their 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.full_title: It's Just Too Much by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: It’s Just Too Much

description.plain:
This boogie-woogie-style rock ‘n’ roll song is best known as being paired in a medley with Sweet Bonnie Brown. There are about 5 recordings that have been released, including one from a bootleg Matrix rehearsal tape. As is canon with The Velvet Underground, this song is improvised, having variations of lyrics between each recording.

At the beginning of the Quine Tapes version, Reed quips, “about five years ago when we used to play it, it was called ‘Ohio Silver’… we don’t call it ‘Ohio Silver’ all too much.”  which suggests that the song dates back to about 1964.

songs.full_title: Ferryboat Bill by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Ferryboat Bill

description.plain:
“Ferryboat Bill” was originally recorded June 19, 1969, during the sessions for The Velvet Underground’s unreleased fourth album.

After the band was dropped by MGM and the album was shelved, this song remained unreleased until Verve included it on the 1986 outtakes compilation Another View.

songs.lyrics:
[Intro]
The next song we like to do... by the way, we haven't done it before here, but I guess we should introduce ourselves. My name is Lou, that's Maureen on drums, that's Sterling over there, and that's my brother Doug on the bass. This a song called "Some Kind of Love", which is a dialogue between a guy named Tom and a girl named Marguerita. He's just trying to drink her like Tequila and she doesn't like being sold through [?], that's what this song's about

[Verse 1]
Some kinds of love, Marguerita told Tom
Between thought and expression lies a lifetime
Situations arise because of the weather
And no kinds of love are better than others

[Verse 2]
Some kinds of love, now Marguerita told Tom
Like a dirty French novel combines the absurd with the vulgar
Now baby some kinds of love, the possibilities are endless
And for me to miss one would seem to be groundless

[Verse 3]
I heard what you said, Marguerita heard Tom
And of course you're a bore but at that you're not charmless
'Cause a bore is a straight line that finds a wealth in division
Some kinds of love are mistaken for vision, whoa
La-de-ta-ta-ta

[Verse 4]
Put jelly on your shoulder
Hey babe, lie down upon the carpet
Let us do what you fear most
But which still makes your eyes moist
[Verse 5]
Oh put jelly on your shoulder, ooh
Lie down upon the carpet
Between thought and expression
Let us now kiss the culprit
Whoa, oh whoa whoa whoa
La-de-ta-ta-ta

[Outro]
I don't know just what it's all about
But put on your red pajamas baby and find out
Whoa whoa whoa
La-de-ta-ta-ta
Whoa whoa whoa whoa
La-de-ta-ta-taEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.lyrics:
[Concert intro]
Good evening
We're your local Velvet Underground
We're glad to see you
Thank You
But we're uh particularly glad on a serious day like today
That people could find that little time to come out and have Some fun to rock and roll
'cause these are serious times
Or I've been told they are
And since they're serious
We felt impelled to do a very serious set
So this is going to be a very serious rock and roll set
And I don't want any of you to enjoy yourselves frivoulously(?)
Because it will run against national policy
Which rhymes by the way, which is how poets are

Anyway...where I come from they arrest people for less than that
And they won't give you a car

This is a song that was written under the influence of dreams
And it's about one man's journey from uptown to downtown

[Verse 1]
I'm waiting for my man
Twenty-six dollars in my hand
Gone up to Lexington, 125
Feeling sick and dirty, more dead than alive
[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 2]
Hey, white boy, what you doin' uptown?
Hey, white boy, you chasin' our women around?
Oh pardon me sir, it's the furthest from my mind
I'm just lookin' for a dear, dear friend of mine

[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 3]
Here he comes, he's all dressed in black...oh woah
PR shoes and a big straw hat
He's never early, he's never late
First thing you learn is you always gotta wait

[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 4]
Time's are getting heavy, I'm so sad
Everyone that was good, you know they all turned out bad
It's not a mystery, no mistake
All I'm gonna have to do is wait
[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 5]
Standing on the corner waiting for the sun to rise
Miss Jean and Miss Anne said they had a surprise
Well it's no mystery, no mistake
I guess I just had to wait

[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 6]
Ever since I was a little boy, I had the strangest dreams
Everything that I saw didn't seem to be what it seem
I'm no wizard, take my speed
Always you know I've got to leave

[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 7]
Gone up to a Brownstone, up three flights of stairs
Everybody’s pinned you, but nobody cares
He’s got the works, gives you sweet taste
Then he's gotta split because he's got no time to waste
[Chorus]
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 8]
Hey baby don’t you holler, darlin' don’t you bawl and shout
I’m feeling good, you know I’m gonna work it on out
I’m feeling good, I’m feeling, oh, so fine
Until tomorrow, but that’s just some other time

[Outro]
I'm waiting for my man (x7)EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: I’m Waiting for the Man

songs.lyrics:
[Intro]
"Good evening. We're the Velvet Underground. [?] Glad you could all make it. This is, uh, our last night here, and I’m glad to see you all showed up. Um, do you people have a curfew or anything like that? Does it matter what time you go home tonight? Do you have school tomorrow? Nobody here has school tomorrow? Yeah, see? 'Cause we could do either one long set or we could do two sets, you know, which ever would make it easier for you. One long? Okay. Okay, then this is gonna go on for a while, so we should get used- get used to each other. Settle back, pull up your cushions, whatever else [?] that makes live bearable in Texas
We saw your cowboys [?] This is a song called 'I’m Waiting for my Man.'"

[Verse 1]
I'm waiting for my man
Got twenty-six dollars in my hand
Up to Lexington, 125
Feeling sick and dirty, more dead than alive
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 2]
Hey, white boy, what you doin' uptown?
Hey, white boy, you chasin' our women around?
Oh pardon me sir, it's the furthest from my mind
I'm just waitin’ for a good, good friend of mine
I’m waiting for my man

[Verse 3]
Here he comes, he's all dressed in black
PR shoes and a big straw hat
He’s never early, he's always late
First thing you learn is that you always gotta wait
I'm waiting for my man

[Verse 4]
Run up to a Brownstone, up three flights of stairs
Now everybody's pinned you, baby, but nobody cares
He’s got the works, gives you sweet taste
Ah, then you gotta split because you got no time to waste
I'm waiting for my man
[Verse 5]
Hey baby don't you holler, oh don't you bawl and shout
I'm feeling good, you know I'm gonna gonna work it on out
I'm feeling good, and oh so fine
Until tomorrow, but that's just some other time
I'm waiting for my man

[Outro]
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man
I'm waiting for my man

"Thank you"EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Winter Song by Ultra Vivid Scene
songs.title: Winter Song

songs.lyrics:
The snow on your eyelids that curtsy with age
Is freezing the stares on tyranny's wings
The bitter is hard and the warmth of your skin
Is diseased with familiar caresses

Withdrawing from splendor and royal decay
Among all the triumphs and jaded awards
The angry and blazing circus of sun
Blasphemes as the crown prince arises

You cannot beget all the sins that you owe
To the people of paradise magic
Pretend to answer passion and form
With foreign rationalizations

Primroses are the jewels that lurk
Among masks of pleasure that flicker with doubt
Embraces of fame that's simultaneously fear
To advance and demand to be recognized

The river shall flow through hollow green faces
Of caricature's resentment etched out of the tongues
Both reluctant princess asleep before birth
The classical sensitive failures

The worshipping wicked cling to the dark of your heart
Lying there and wait with your angels
Moan and ravish from dawn to dusk
The avaricious young loversEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.lyrics:

But don't forget the knife that was thrust

Turn to fly, go away
Little bird, please don't stay
Fare thee well

Running into the sea
Where shadows choose their horrors
Designed for music

Turn to fly, go away
Little bird, please don't stay
Fare thee wellEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Sweet Jane (Version 1 / Live At The Matrix, San Francisco) by The Velvet Underground
songs.title: Sweet Jane (Version 1 / Live At The Matrix, San Francisco)
songs.title_with_featured: Sweet Jane (Version 1 / Live At The Matrix, San Francisco)

description.plain:
This recording of ‘Sweet Jane’ is the first recording and live performance of the song. It would later be released on the very popular 1970 album, Loaded.

This version was recorded Monday night, November 17th, at the Matrix- which was owned (2 years prior) none other than Marty Balin of Jefferson Airplane. However, his part was sold and the new owners who booked them supposedly hated the Velvet Underground, and wished for them to fail on stage.

body.plain:
This recording of ‘Sweet Jane’ is the first recording and live performance of the song. It would later be released on the very popular 1970 album, Loaded.

This version was recorded Monday night, November 17th, at the Matrix- which was owned (2 years prior) none other than Marty Balin of Jefferson Airplane. However, his part was sold and the new owners who booked them supposedly hated the Velvet Underground, and wished for them to fail on stage.

songs.lyrics:
Anyone whoever had a heart
Wouldn't turn around and break it
And anyone who's ever played a part
Wouldn't turn around and hate it

Sweet Jane
Sweet Jane
Oh, sweet, sweet Jane

Aw, waitin' down on the corner
Miss Jimmy and Miss Anne
They said, "Let's go up to Billy's house
He's got a couple of strange friends there"
So I went up to the fourth floor
And much to my surprise
Nobody looked at my body
They were all lookin' at my eyes

Oh, sweet Jane
Oh sweet Jane
Oh, sweet, sweet Jane

Well Saturday down by the river
Everybody said that it was going to overflow
And me I had no money for a taxi
So I figured I'd better find some place to go
So I met the strangest lady
She said that she'd make me a movie star
And she was all dressed in orange
And she had a great maroon car
But anyone whoever had a heart
Wouldn't turn around and break it
And anyone whoever played a part
Wouldn't turn around and hate it

Sweet Jane
Oh, sweet Jane
Oh, sweet, sweet Jane

Heavenly wine and roses
Seem to look upon me when you smile
Heavenly wine and roses
Seem to look upon me when you smile

La, la, la, la, la, la, la, la
La, la, la, la, la, la, la, la
La, la, la, la, la, la, la, la
La, la, la, la, la, la, la, la

Sweet Jane
Sweet Jane
Oh, sweet, sweet JaneEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
